Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Reproductive Isolation, Speciation and Floral Evolution in Pedicularis

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant titled "Reproductive Isolation, Speciation and Floral Evolution in Pedicularis" was awarded to Deren Eaton to support collaborative research in China during the summer of 2010.

The Hengduan Mountains of south-central China are of great interest to the study of biodiversity, exhibiting greater levels of plant species richness and endemism than expected given their temperate climate and latitude. Pedicularis is one of the most diverse lineages in this region with nearly 270 endemic species which frequently co-occur. This provides a natural setting to test a long standing theory in ecology and evolution; namely, that species interactions accelerate rates of adaptation and speciation. More specificially, we test the hypothesis that competition for pollination among co-occurring, sychronously flowering, species of Pedicularis increases rates of floral divergence through selection for character displacement, and that floral differences between populations affect gene-flow.

We focused on the geographically widespread species Pedicularis cranolopha. Throughout its range in Sichuan and Yunnan Provinces we observed substantial intraspecific variation in P. cranolopha, and found it to co-occur with a mosaic of different Pedicularis species. Floral differences among populations do not correlate with geographic distances, suggesting local adaptation at relatively fine spatial scales.

Samples from these populations are now being sequenced for genetic markers using high-throughput technology. By accounting for relatedness among populations the effects of local co-occurring species on floral phenotypes will be assessed using novel statistical comparative methods. In this way we will learn how variation in species interactions affects the evolution of floral phenotypes and reproductive isolation.

This research has broad implications for understanding patterns of biodiversity and the process of speciation. To the extent interspecific species interactions promote the evolution of intraspecific floral divergence, this would indicate a long term evolutionary significance to the preservation of community-wide biodiversity for its effect on the maintenance of genetic diversity within species.
